questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD by his wife complaining about difficulty in expressing emotions and not taking part in daily activities. On examination, resting tremors and rigidity are noted. Given the possible diagnosis, which part of the brain is affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Basal ganglia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The basal ganglia are the primary brain structures affected in Parkinson's disease , leading to both motor (e.g., tremors, rigidity) and non-motor (e.g., emotional flatness) symptoms.
  • ➤ basal ganglia
  • ➤ Parkinson's disease

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Subacute combined degeneration of cord
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Subacute combined degeneration of cord

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subacute combined degeneration (SACD. of the spinal cord is caused by vitamin B12 deficiency and involves demyelination of the dorsal columns and corticospinal tracts, leading to sensory loss, UMN-type weakness, and other neurological deficits. Early treatment with vitamin B12 is essential.
  • ➤ Subacute combined degeneration (SACD. of the spinal cord
  • ➤ vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of convulsions and visual hallucinations. She does not talk to anyone and keeps looking at the sky. Pathological examination shows the presence of Lewy bodies within the neurons. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Parkinson's disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parkinson's disease can progress to involve dementia and visual hallucinations in advanced stages, and its pathology includes Lewy bodies in neurons.
  • ➤ Parkinson's disease
  • ➤ Lewy bodies

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. The chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pancoast tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pancoast tumor is a lung cancer at the apex of the lung that can invade the sympathetic chain and brachial plexus, causing Horner's syndrome, shoulder/arm pain, and neurological deficits in the C8-T1 distribution. Chronic smoking is the most common risk factor.
  • ➤ Pancoast tumor

questions.text: In the anatomical arrangement of intermuscular spaces such as the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, anatomical snuff box, etc., what primarily forms the roof of these spaces? Skin Superficial fascia Subcutaneous fat , cutaneous nerves and vessels Deep fascia
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The roof of intermuscular spaces such as the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, and anatomical snuff box is formed by the skin, superficial fascia, subcutaneous fat with cutaneous nerves and vessels, and deep fascia. All these layers must be considered during surgical approaches or dissection.
  • ➤ roof
  • ➤ cubital fossa, femoral triangle, and anatomical snuff box
  • ➤ skin, superficial fascia, subcutaneous fat with cutaneous nerves and vessels, and deep fascia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with anterior knee pain that worsens with activities like running and jumping. On physical examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the front of the knee. Palpation reveals a small, round, bony prominence at the centre of the knee. The patient reports no recent trauma. You will put the involved bone in which of the following type
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sesamoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patella , the largest sesamoid bone , is located within the quadriceps femoris tendon and serves to improve leverage and reduce friction at the knee joint. Conditions involving this bone often present with anterior knee pain, particularly during activities like running or jumping.
  • ➤ patella
  • ➤ sesamoid bone

questions.text: A 21 years old patient Suyash came to OPD with history of fall on hand. Now he is having pain at hand region. X ray of patient is given. Which of the following joint has been shown in his X ray ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ellipsoid joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The radiocarpal (wrist) joint is an ellipsoid joint that allows a variety of movements, including flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. This makes it unique from other joint types like hinge or saddle joints.
  • ➤ radiocarpal (wrist) joint
  • ➤ ellipsoid joint

questions.text: What is the typical fiber arrangement of lumbrical muscles in the hand?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 st & 2 nd lumbricals – Unipennate, 3 rd & 4 th lumbricals - bipennate

options.label: B
options.text: 1 st & 2 nd lumbricals – bipennate, 3 rd & 4 th lumbricals - unipennate

options.label: C
options.text: 1 st & 3 rd lumbricals – bipennate, 2 nd & 4 th lumbricals - unipennate

options.label: D
options.text: 2 nd & 3 rd lumbricals – bipennate, 1 st & 4 th lumbricals - unipennate

questions.correct_answer: A. 1 st & 2 nd lumbricals – Unipennate, 3 rd & 4 th lumbricals - bipennate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1st& 2ndlumbricals – Unipennate, 3rd& 4thlumbricals – bipennate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lumbrical muscles of the hand have a unipennate arrangement for the 1st and 2nd lumbricals and a bipennate arrangement for the 3rd and 4th lumbricals. This fiber arrangement is crucial for the fine motor control of the fingers.
  • ➤ lumbrical muscles
  • ➤ unipennate
  • ➤ bipennate

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after falling onto her outstretched hand. She complains of severe pain in her elbow. Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness over the distal humerus. An X-ray confirms a supracondylar fracture. Upon further examination, the patient is unable to flex her thumb. Which nerve is most likely involved in this patient's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior interosseous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anterior interosseous nerve , a branch of the median nerve , is commonly affected in supracondylar fractures of the humerus . This leads to an inability to flex the thumb, which is a key clinical feature in diagnosing anterior interosseous nerve injury.
  • ➤ anterior interosseous nerve
  • ➤ median nerve
  • ➤ supracondylar fractures of the humerus

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was admitted with complaints of acute pain in the right shoulder of three-days duration associated with swelling and he also had difficulty in using his right shoulder since then. Pain was sudden at onset, continuous, and moderate to severe in intensity and it was aggravated on activity. In addition, he had severe night and rest pain. He also gave a history of intramuscular injection of Iron in the right deltoid region 2 weeks previously, which was administered in a local clinic. On examination, there was a globular swelling in the lateral aspect of the right arm extending up to the scapular region. There was a local rise of temperature and tenderness over the swelling, painful restriction of the right shoulder movements and he could not abduct his arm to the right angle. MRI scan of the right shoulder showed pyomyositis of the posterior belly of the right deltoid muscle with central abscess formation. Which among the following is not a possible complication that can be expected in this case if untreated?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm

options.label: C
options.text: Weak flexion of arm at shoulder joint

options.label: D
options.text: Inability to extend the arm at shoulder joint

questions.correct_answer: A. Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Loss of sensation on the lower lateral aspect of the arm is not a possible complication in this case because the axillary nerve supplies the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm , not the lower lateral region. This distinguishes it from other complications that arise from axillary nerve involvement or deltoid dysfunction.
  • ➤ Loss of sensation on the lower lateral aspect of the arm
  • ➤ axillary nerve
  • ➤ upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm

questions.text: All of the following muscles have dual nerve supply except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pronator teres

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Pronator teres muscle is not a hybrid muscle, as it is supplied solely by the median nerve , while all the other muscles in the question (subscapularis, pectoralis major, flexor digitorum profundus) receive dual nerve supply.
  • ➤ Pronator teres
  • ➤ median nerve

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of prolonged crutch use due to a leg injury presents with weakness in his hand. He reports difficulty extending his wrist and fingers and a decreased sensation on the back of his hand. These symptoms have progressively worsened over the past few weeks. Which of the following structures is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior cord

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radial nerve dysfunction (e.g., wrist and finger drop) can occur due to compression or injury to the posterior cord of the brachial plexus , as seen in cases of prolonged crutch use or direct trauma. The posterior cord is the origin of the radial and axillary nerves.
  • ➤ Radial nerve dysfunction
  • ➤ posterior cord of the brachial plexus
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: A 45-year-old office worker complains of persistent wrist pain and difficulty performing repetitive tasks on a computer keyboard. Physical examination reveals tenderness at the wrist joint and decreased range of motion, particularly during wrist flexion and extension. Radiographic evaluation shows evidence of degenerative changes in the joint space. Which of the following bones is not directly involved in the formation of the wrist joint ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ulna

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ulna is not directly involved in the wrist joint due to the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) , which separates it from the carpal bones. The wrist joint is primarily formed by the radius , scaphoid , lunate , and partially the triquetral bones.
  • ➤ ulna
  • ➤ triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC)
  • ➤ radius
  • ➤ scaphoid
  • ➤ lunate
  • ➤ triquetral

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes is admitted to the hospital with complaints of weakness in the hand and difficulty holding objects. The patient's medical history includes a recent cerebrovascular accident (CVA). A "card test" is performed as part of the neurological examination. Which of the following muscle groups is primarily assessed with this test to check for motor function in the hand?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Palmar interossei

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The card test is used to evaluate the palmar interossei , which are responsible for adducting the fingers and are innervated by the ulnar nerve . This test helps identify motor deficits associated with ulnar nerve dysfunction.
  • ➤ card test
  • ➤ palmar interossei
  • ➤ adducting the fingers
  • ➤ ulnar nerve

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with complaints of progressive weakness in his right hand. The patient reports difficulty in fine movements of hand. Doctor performed a test over patient as shown in image. Which of the following statements is true about the given image?

options.label: A
options.text: The median nerve of the right hand is injured.

options.label: B
options.text: There is weakness of thenar muscles on the right side

options.label: C
options.text: The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak

options.label: D
options.text: The flexor muscles of the thumb of the right hand are weak

questions.correct_answer: C. The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The adductor pollicis muscle is primarily responsible for thumb adduction and is innervated by the ulnar nerve . A positive Froment's sign indicates ulnar nerve dysfunction , which affects the adductor pollicis muscle.
  • ➤ adductor pollicis muscle
  • ➤ ulnar nerve
  • ➤ Froment's sign
  • ➤ ulnar nerve dysfunction

questions.text: A 75-year-old female presented to the medicine OPD with complaints of numbness over her little finger of the right hand. On examination, there was total loss of cutaneous sensation over the palmar and dorsal surface of the little finger of the right hand. Which of the following nerves is probably injured?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ulnar nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ulnar nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the palmar and dorsal surfaces of the little finger . Loss of sensation in this area is a hallmark of ulnar nerve injury.
  • ➤ ulnar nerve
  • ➤ palmar and dorsal surfaces of the little finger

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a complaint of dragging his foot while walking. On examination, he demonstrates difficulty in dorsiflexing his foot at the ankle. This clinical presentation is most likely due to a lesion affecting which nerve?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Deep Peroneal (Fibular) Nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Foot drop , characterized by the inability to dorsiflex the foot, is caused by injury to the common peroneal nerve or its branch, the deep peroneal nerve , which innervates the anterior compartment muscles of the leg. If the common peroneal nerve is not an option, the deep peroneal nerve is the best answer.
  • ➤ Foot drop
  • ➤ common peroneal nerve
  • ➤ deep peroneal nerve
  • ➤ common peroneal nerve
  • ➤ deep peroneal nerve

questions.text: A 47-year-old obese man felt a snap in his right lower leg while playing squash and couldn’t continue the game further. He reached the emergency department with complaints of acute severe pain in his right lower leg and heel. The physician confirmed a diagnosis of an acute right Achilles tendon rupture and the patient was immediately posted for open reparative surgery. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes dorsiflexion of foot at the ankle joint

options.label: B
options.text: It is supplied by superficial peroneal nerve

options.label: C
options.text: It is the strongest tendon of the human body

options.label: D
options.text: Its inserts into the upper third of calcaneus

questions.correct_answer: C. It is the strongest tendon of the human body
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is the strongest tendon of the human body

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Achilles tendon is the strongest tendon of the human body and plays a crucial role in plantar flexion of the foot. It is innervated by the tibial nerve and inserts on the posterior surface of the calcaneus .
  • ➤ Achilles tendon
  • ➤ strongest tendon of the human body
  • ➤ plantar flexion
  • ➤ tibial nerve
  • ➤ posterior surface of the calcaneus

questions.text: A 22 year old male athlete sustained an injury to his foot during one of his practice sessions. The given image is the x-ray of his foot. Which of the following statements is true pertaining to the given image?

options.label: A
options.text: It is fracture of first metatarsal base

options.label: B
options.text: It is a fracture of fifth metatarsal base

options.label: C
options.text: The tuberosity of the pointed bone in the above image is least vascular

options.label: D
options.text: Its metadiaphyseal region receives the insertion of peroneus tertius tendon

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a fracture of fifth metatarsal base
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is a fracture of fifth metatarsal base

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The X-ray demonstrates a Jones fracture involving the base of the fifth metatarsal. This is a common injury in athletes and is associated with the insertion of the peroneus brevis tendon on the tuberosity. Proper diagnosis and treatment are crucial due to the potential for delayed union or non-union in this region.
  • ➤ Jones fracture
  • ➤ peroneus brevis tendon

questions.text: A 22-year-old athlete presents with pain in the posterior aspect of his hip after a sprinting injury. On examination, the pain is localized to the ischial tuberosity. Which of the following muscles is most likely involved, given its attachment to the ischial tuberosity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Biceps Femoris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ischial tuberosity serves as the origin for the hamstring muscles , including the biceps femoris , which is commonly injured in sprinting-related activities due to its role in knee flexion and hip extension. Among the options, biceps femoris is the most likely muscle involved in this injury.
  • ➤ ischial tuberosity
  • ➤ hamstring muscles
  • ➤ biceps femoris
  • ➤ biceps femoris

questions.text: Patient presented with a sagging face, asymmetrical smile, facial muscle tone with drooping of left angle of mouth, eyelid with drooping corners and inability to blow properly. Which Nerve is involved in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Facial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for motor control of facial expression. Dysfunction, such as in Bell's palsy , results in facial drooping, asymmetry, and inability to perform facial tasks like smiling or blowing.
  • ➤ facial nerve (cranial nerve VII)
  • ➤ Bell's palsy

questions.text: Injury to the nerve that lies medially to the structure pointed will result in?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of taste sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of taste sensation from posterior 1/3 tongue

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of general sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of taste sensation from posterior most part of tongue

questions.correct_answer: A. Loss of taste sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Loss of taste sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The chorda tympani nerve is responsible for taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue . Injury to the nerve medially related to the structure in the image results in the loss of taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue , making A the correct answer.
  • ➤ chorda tympani nerve
  • ➤ taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue
  • ➤ loss of taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue
  • ➤ A

questions.text: A 28 year old male sustained head injury due to fall from his bike.CT brain showed extradural hematoma.The blood vessel injured is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Middle meningeal artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An extradural hematoma is typically caused by rupture of the middle meningeal artery , often following trauma to the pterion , where this artery is particularly vulnerable. This results in an arterial bleed into the extradural space, creating a lens-shaped hematoma on CT imaging.
  • ➤ extradural hematoma
  • ➤ middle meningeal artery
  • ➤ pterion

questions.text: A 57 year old man underwent parotidectomy following which he complained that there was loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is affected most?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Greater auricular nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The greater auricular nerve (C2, C3) supplies sensory innervation to the angle of the mandible and the area overlying the parotid gland. Its injury during a parotidectomy can lead to loss of sensation in the shaving area .
  • ➤ greater auricular nerve
  • ➤ parotidectomy
  • ➤ loss of sensation in the shaving area

questions.text: A student after a heavy lunch from the hostel got ready for his afternoon class. He sat in the first bench and began to take notes. After a while he yawned widely.To his surprise sadly he could not close his mouth. The jaw was stuck.Which of the following statement is not true in the above scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: This is a case of anterior dislocation of temporomandibular joint

options.label: B
options.text: Temporomandibular joint is a bicondylar type of synovial joint

options.label: C
options.text: Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible

options.label: D
options.text: Sphenomandibular ligament is situated medial to temporomandibular joint

questions.correct_answer: C. Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral pterygoid muscle is the only muscle of mastication responsible for depressing the mandible , whereas the medial pterygoid elevates it. Injury or excessive opening can cause anterior dislocation of the TMJ , leaving the jaw stuck open.
  • ➤ lateral pterygoid muscle
  • ➤ depressing the mandible
  • ➤ medial pterygoid
  • ➤ anterior dislocation of the TMJ

questions.text: Identify the epithelium:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The keratinized stratified squamous epithelium is a defining feature of the skin's epidermis , offering protection against mechanical stress, dehydration, and microbial invasion.
  • ➤ keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
  • ➤ skin's epidermis

questions.text: Laboratory studies in the outpatient clinic on a 24-year-old female included assessment of circulating blood chemistry. Which of the following arteries is most likely at risk during veni puncture at the cubital fossa?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Brachial

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During venipuncture at the cubital fossa , the brachial artery is the structure most at risk due to its location just deep to the median cubital vein and the bicipital aponeurosis . Proper technique is critical to avoid arterial injury.
  • ➤ cubital fossa
  • ➤ brachial artery
  • ➤ median cubital vein
  • ➤ bicipital aponeurosis

questions.text: Identify the cell:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Astrocytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Astrocytes are star-shaped glial cells of the CNS that play crucial roles in maintaining the blood-brain barrier, providing metabolic support, and regulating neuronal microenvironments. The star-like morphology seen in the image confirms the identification as astrocytes .
  • ➤ star-shaped glial cells
  • ➤ astrocytes
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Central Nervous System (CNS) Cells
  • ➤ Central Nervous System (CNS) Cells
  • ➤ Types: Excitable Cells: Neurons (functional units of the nervous system). Non-Excitable Cells: Glial cells (supporting cells).
  • ➤ Types: Excitable Cells: Neurons (functional units of the nervous system). Non-Excitable Cells: Glial cells (supporting cells).
  • ➤ Types:
  • ➤ Excitable Cells: Neurons (functional units of the nervous system). Non-Excitable Cells: Glial cells (supporting cells).
  • ➤ Excitable Cells: Neurons (functional units of the nervous system).
  • ➤ Excitable Cells:
  • ➤ Non-Excitable Cells: Glial cells (supporting cells).
  • ➤ Non-Excitable Cells:
  • ➤ Types of Glial Cells:
  • ➤ Types of Glial Cells:
  • ➤ Macroglial Cells:
  • ➤ Macroglial Cells:
  • ➤ Astrocytes : Shape: Star-shaped. Functions: Formation of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) . Support for neurons. Regulation of ionic balance. Removal of excess neurotransmitters. Oligodendrocytes : Responsible for myelination in the CNS . Fewer processes compared to astrocytes. Ependymal Cells : Flat or cuboidal cells. Line the brain ventricles and spinal cord central canal. Involved in the production and circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) . Microglial Cells: Function: Act as phagocytic cells, removing debris and pathogens in the CNS.
  • ➤ Astrocytes : Shape: Star-shaped. Functions: Formation of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) . Support for neurons. Regulation of ionic balance. Removal of excess neurotransmitters.
  • ➤ Astrocytes
  • ➤ Shape: Star-shaped. Functions: Formation of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) . Support for neurons. Regulation of ionic balance. Removal of excess neurotransmitters.
  • ➤ Shape: Star-shaped.
  • ➤ Shape:
  • ➤ Functions: Formation of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) . Support for neurons. Regulation of ionic balance. Removal of excess neurotransmitters.
  • ➤ Functions:
  • ➤ Formation of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) . Support for neurons. Regulation of ionic balance. Removal of excess neurotransmitters.
  • ➤ Formation of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) .
  • ➤ blood-brain barrier (BBB)
  • ➤ Support for neurons.
  • ➤ Regulation of ionic balance.
  • ➤ Removal of excess neurotransmitters.
  • ➤ Oligodendrocytes : Responsible for myelination in the CNS . Fewer processes compared to astrocytes.
  • ➤ Oligodendrocytes
  • ➤ Responsible for myelination in the CNS . Fewer processes compared to astrocytes.
  • ➤ Responsible for myelination in the CNS .
  • ➤ myelination in the CNS
  • ➤ Fewer processes compared to astrocytes.
  • ➤ Ependymal Cells : Flat or cuboidal cells. Line the brain ventricles and spinal cord central canal. Involved in the production and circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) .
  • ➤ Ependymal Cells
  • ➤ Flat or cuboidal cells. Line the brain ventricles and spinal cord central canal. Involved in the production and circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) .
  • ➤ Flat or cuboidal cells.
  • ➤ Line the brain ventricles and spinal cord central canal.
  • ➤ Involved in the production and circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) .
  • ➤ cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
  • ➤ Microglial Cells: Function: Act as phagocytic cells, removing debris and pathogens in the CNS.
  • ➤ Microglial Cells:
  • ➤ Function: Act as phagocytic cells, removing debris and pathogens in the CNS.
  • ➤ Function: Act as phagocytic cells, removing debris and pathogens in the CNS.
  • ➤ Function:
  • ➤ Myelination:
  • ➤ Myelination:
  • ➤ CNS Myelination: Done by oligodendrocytes . PNS Myelination: Done by Schwann cells .
  • ➤ CNS Myelination: Done by oligodendrocytes .
  • ➤ CNS Myelination:
  • ➤ oligodendrocytes
  • ➤ PNS Myelination: Done by Schwann cells .
  • ➤ PNS Myelination:
  • ➤ Schwann cells
  • ➤ Schwann Cells (Peripheral Nervous System):
  • ➤ Schwann Cells (Peripheral Nervous System):
  • ➤ Derived from the term "Schwann" (means dog in Sanskrit as a memory aid). Responsible for myelinating axons in the PNS.
  • ➤ Derived from the term "Schwann" (means dog in Sanskrit as a memory aid).
  • ➤ Responsible for myelinating axons in the PNS.
  • ➤ Key Insights on Astrocytes:
  • ➤ Key Insights on Astrocytes:
  • ➤ Astrocytes extend processes to connect with blood vessels and neurons. They are essential for regulating the environment around neurons and maintaining the CNS's structural integrity.
  • ➤ Astrocytes extend processes to connect with blood vessels and neurons.
  • ➤ They are essential for regulating the environment around neurons and maintaining the CNS's structural integrity.

questions.text: Muscle used for Tendon grafting operation in lower limb is.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Plantaris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The plantaris muscle is the most used for tendon grafting in the lower limb due to its long tendon , ease of harvesting, and minimal impact on limb function. For the upper limb , the palmaris longus is the equivalent choice.
  • ➤ plantaris muscle
  • ➤ tendon grafting in the lower limb
  • ➤ long tendon
  • ➤ upper limb
  • ➤ palmaris longus

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is admitted to the hospital with a painful arm after a “strongest man in the world” contest. Physical examination gives evidence of a rupture of the long tendon of the biceps brachii (Figure). Which of the following is the most likely location of the rupture?

options.label: C
options.text: Junction with the short head of the biceps muscle

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intertubercular groove

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The intertubercular groove is the most common site of rupture of the long head of the biceps brachii tendon , resulting in the characteristic Popeye sign .
  • ➤ intertubercular groove
  • ➤ long head of the biceps brachii tendon
  • ➤ Popeye sign

questions.text: Achalasia cardia is due to.
questions.correct_answer: B. Abnormality in neural crest cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Abnormality in neural crest cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Achalasia cardia is due to an abnormality in neural crest cells , leading to dysfunction of the Auerbach's plexus and failure of LES relaxation. This causes a functional obstruction and dilatation of the esophagus.
  • ➤ Achalasia cardia
  • ➤ abnormality in neural crest cells
  • ➤ Auerbach's plexus

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is treated at the hospital after he fell from his bicycle. Radiographic examination reveals fractures both of the tibia and the fibula. On physical examination the patient has a foot drop, but normal eversion (Figure). Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Deep fibular (peroneal)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Foot drop with normal eversion strongly suggests an injury to the deep fibular (peroneal) nerve , as it innervates the dorsiflexors of the foot.
  • ➤ Foot drop with normal eversion
  • ➤ deep fibular (peroneal) nerve

questions.text: Morphine acts on:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) B & C Both correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Morphine acts on the substantia gelatinosa and Rexed lamina II , both located in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord , to suppress pain signals by binding to opioid receptors.
  • ➤ Morphine acts on the substantia gelatinosa and Rexed lamina II
  • ➤ dorsal horn of the spinal cord

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department after an injury to his foot while playing football with his college friends. An MRI examination reveals multiple tendinous tears (Figure). Which of the following bones is associated with the muscle tears?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Calcaneus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of Achilles tendon injury or tear, the calcaneus is the associated bone, as it serves as the insertion site for the Achilles tendon . This bone and tendon are critical for plantarflexion and locomotion.
  • ➤ calcaneus
  • ➤ Achilles tendon

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect option?

options.label: A
options.text: A & B are not having any nuclei but C is having nuclei

options.label: B
options.text: B forms anterior boundary of interpeduncular fossa & C is not the content of interpeduncular fossa

options.label: C
options.text: Chief sensory nucleus of trigeminal nerve is situated in D & Corticospinal tract passes through E

options.label: D
options.text: XIII cranial nerve is situated near A, XII cranial nerve is attached between E & F while IX, X & XI cranial nerve are attached behind F

questions.correct_answer: B. B forms anterior boundary of interpeduncular fossa & C is not the content of interpeduncular fossa
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B forms anterior boundary of interpeduncular fossa & C is not the content of interpeduncular fossa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The incorrect statement is B , as the oculomotor nerve (C. is indeed a content of the interpeduncular fossa , contrary to the claim in the option.
  • ➤ B
  • ➤ oculomotor nerve (C.
  • ➤ interpeduncular fossa

questions.text: A 49-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with a cold and pale foot. Physical examination reveals that the patient suffers from peripheral vascular disease and his popliteal artery is occluded and no pulse is felt upon palpation. What is the landmark to feel the pulse of the femoral artery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Femoral triangle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The femoral artery pulse is best palpated in the femoral triangle , particularly at the mid-inguinal point . This is the key landmark for evaluating femoral artery flow.
  • ➤ femoral artery
  • ➤ femoral triangle
  • ➤ mid-inguinal point

questions.text: V th ventricle of the brain is related to.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fifth ventricle , when present, is associated with the septum pellucidum (C) . It is an anatomical variation and not a functional ventricle.
  • ➤ fifth ventricle
  • ➤ septum pellucidum (C)

questions.text: During cardiac catheterization of a 6-year-old child, the radiologist notes that the contrast medium released into the arch of the aorta is visible immediately in the left pulmonary artery. What is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Patent ductus arteriosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) allows blood to flow abnormally from the aorta into the pulmonary artery, explaining the immediate appearance of contrast medium in the pulmonary artery during catheterization.
  • ➤ patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding brain sections are correct except?

options.label: A
options.text: Lesion at C will result in Paralytic agitans & lesion at F will result in disturbance in Papez circuit

options.label: B
options.text: B is considered as 5 th lobe of brain & F is considered a part of 6 th lobe of brain

options.label: C
options.text: A is not the part of basal nuclei while F is not the part of Limbic system

options.label: D
options.text: D is the example of largest commissural fibre & E is afferent for the mammilary body

questions.correct_answer: C. A is not the part of basal nuclei while F is not the part of Limbic system
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A is not the part of basal nuclei while F is not the part of Limbic system

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The incorrect statement is C , as both the claustrum (A) is part of the basal nuclei, and the hippocampus (F) is part of the limbic system.
  • ➤ incorrect statement
  • ➤ C
  • ➤ claustrum (A)
  • ➤ hippocampus (F)

questions.text: In given radiological anatomy image identify the thalamus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In radiological anatomy, the thalamus is identified as the large, centrally located structure, marked as C in this image.
  • ➤ thalamus
  • ➤ C

questions.text: Lesion to indicated structure will result in paralysis of which of the following muscle
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Risoreus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lesion to the facial colliculus will primarily affect the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) , causing paralysis of muscles of facial expression such as Risorius . The lateral rectus muscle (abducens nerve, cranial nerve VI) may also be affected secondarily, but facial muscles take precedence.
  • ➤ lesion to the facial colliculus
  • ➤ facial nerve (cranial nerve VII)
  • ➤ Risorius
  • ➤ lateral rectus muscle

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is admitted to the hospital with severe dyspnea. Physical examination reveals that the patient is suffering from an asthma attack, with associated bronchospasm. Which of the following nerves is responsible for the innervation of the bronchial smooth muscle cells?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vagus nerve is responsible for the parasympathetic innervation of bronchial smooth muscle cells, causing bronchoconstriction through activation of muscarinic receptors. This mechanism is central to asthma-related bronchospasm.
  • ➤ vagus nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is the action of indicated muscle:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Protraction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral pterygoid muscle is primarily responsible for protraction of the mandible during jaw movements.
  • ➤ lateral pterygoid muscle
  • ➤ protraction

questions.text: A 3-year-old male who fell from a tree complains of severe pain over the right side of his chest because of a rib fracture at the midaxillary line. He is admitted to the hospital due to his difficulty breathing. Radiographic and physical examinations reveal atelectasis, resulting from the accumulation of blood in his pleural space and resulting hemothorax. What is the most likely the source of bleeding to cause the hemothorax?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intercostal vessels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of rib fractures, the intercostal vessels are the most common source of bleeding leading to a hemothorax, due to their location along the inferior border of the ribs in the costal groove.
  • ➤ intercostal vessels

questions.text: In Pringle’s menuvere method which anatomical structure is mainly compressed
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Portal vein & hepatic artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During Pringle’s maneuver , the portal vein and hepatic artery are compressed by clamping the hepatoduodenal ligament , effectively controlling liver bleeding. D is the correct answer.
  • ➤ Pringle’s maneuver
  • ➤ portal vein
  • ➤ hepatic artery
  • ➤ hepatoduodenal ligament
  • ➤ D

questions.text: Fusion of the caudal portions of the kidneys during embryonic development is most likely to result in which of the following congenital conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Horseshoe kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fusion of the caudal poles of the kidneys during development results in a horseshoe kidney , which is typically located at or below the L3-L4 level due to entrapment by the inferior mesenteric artery.
  • ➤ horseshoe kidney

questions.text: Portal vein is formed at level of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) L2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The portal vein is formed at the L2 vertebral level , behind the neck of the pancreas , by the union of the superior mesenteric vein (SMV) and the splenic vein .
  • ➤ portal vein
  • ➤ L2 vertebral level
  • ➤ behind the neck of the pancreas
  • ➤ superior mesenteric vein (SMV)
  • ➤ splenic vein

questions.text: A 54-year-old male is admitted to the emergency department with severe upper abdominal pain. Gastroscopy reveals a tumor in the antrum of the stomach. A CT scan is ordered to evaluate lymphatic drainage of the stomach. Which of the following lymph nodes is most likely to be involved in a malignancy of the stomach?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Celiac

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The celiac lymph nodes are the primary lymphatic drainage nodes for the stomach and are most likely to be involved in malignancies originating from the stomach.
  • ➤ celiac lymph nodes

questions.text: The appearance of the colon on double contrast barium enema examination is shown in image. Identify the A,B & C respectively

options.label: A
options.text: Hepatic flexure, splenic flexure, transverse colon

options.label: C
options.text: Splenic flexure, Hepatic flexure, , transverse colon

questions.correct_answer: C. Splenic flexure, Hepatic flexure, , transverse colon
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Splenic  flexure, Hepatic flexure, , transverse colon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a double-contrast barium enema , the anatomical sequence of the large intestine in the image aligns with hepatic flexure (A) , splenic flexure (B) , and transverse colon (C) .
  • ➤ double-contrast barium enema
  • ➤ hepatic flexure (A)
  • ➤ splenic flexure (B)
  • ➤ transverse colon (C)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male entered the emergency department with a complaint of severe abdominal pain. During physical examination it is observed that his cremasteric reflex is absent. Which of the following nerves is responsible for the efferent limb of the cremasteric reflex?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Genitofemoral

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The efferent limb of the cremasteric reflex is mediated by the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve .
  • ➤ genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: At which level of brain, the nucleus supplying to the marked muscle is situated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Superior colliculus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oculomotor nerve nucleus lies at the level of the superior colliculus in the midbrain. This is the key to answering questions related to the medial rectus muscle.
  • ➤ The oculomotor nerve nucleus lies at the level of the superior colliculus in the midbrain. This is the key to answering questions related to the medial rectus muscle.
  • ➤ oculomotor nerve nucleus
  • ➤ superior colliculus

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital after suffering a ruptured spleen in a skiing accident. Physical examination reveals intense pain that radiates to the region of the left shoulder, presumably due to irritation of the diaphragm. Which of the following signs best describes this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kehr sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kehr sign is the referred pain in the left shoulder due to irritation of the diaphragm, commonly caused by conditions such as ruptured spleen or diaphragmatic irritation, mediated via the phrenic nerve.
  • ➤ Kehr sign

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is admitted to the hospital due to severe back pain. Radiographic examination reveals severe osteoporosis of the vertebral column, with crush fractures of vertebrae L4 and L5. Which of the following parts of the vertebrae are most likely to be fractured in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vertebral bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In osteoporosis, vertebral bodies are the most likely parts of the vertebrae to sustain crush fractures due to their role in bearing the axial load of the spine, especially in weight-bearing lumbar regions.
  • ➤ vertebral bodies

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency department after a car crash. Radiographic examination reveals a whiplash injury in addition to hyperextension of her cervical spine. Which of the following ligaments will most likely be injured?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anterior longitudinal ligament

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hyperextension injuries of the cervical spine, such as those seen in whiplash injuries during car crashes, the anterior longitudinal ligament is most likely to be injured.
  • ➤ anterior longitudinal ligament

questions.text: Most lateral nucleus of cerebellum?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dentate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The dentate nucleus is the most lateral and largest nucleus of the cerebellum and is essential for motor coordination.
  • ➤ dentate nucleus
  • ➤ most lateral and largest nucleus

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after an injury sustained at work in a factory. He presents with severe scalp lacerations, which were sutured. After three days the wound is inflammed, swollen, and painful. Between which tissue layers is the infection most likely located?

options.label: C
options.text: The dense connective tissue and the aponeurosis

options.label: D
options.text: The dense connective tissue and the skin

questions.correct_answer: B. The aponeurosis and the periosteum
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The aponeurosis and the periosteum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infections following scalp lacerations typically localize in the loose areolar connective tissue , located between the aponeurosis and the pericranium , due to its potential space for fluid and pathogen spread.
  • ➤ loose areolar connective tissue
  • ➤ aponeurosis and the pericranium

questions.text: A kind of hernia is shown in the image. Which anatomical structure is not present in the boundary of related space?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trapezius

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trapezius muscle is not part of the boundaries of Petit’s triangle , which is a site for lumbar hernia formation. The boundaries are formed by the latissimus dorsi , external oblique , and iliac crest .
  • ➤ trapezius muscle
  • ➤ not part of the boundaries of Petit’s triangle
  • ➤ latissimus dorsi
  • ➤ external oblique
  • ➤ iliac crest

questions.text: 54-year-old man was admitted to the emergency department after he was struck by an automobile. Radiographic examination revealed a fracture through the crista galli of the anterior cranial fossa, resulting in slow, local bleeding. Which of the following is the most likely source of bleeding?

options.label: B
options.text: The great cerebral vein of Galen

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Superior sagittal sinus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fracture through the crista galli of the anterior cranial fossa is most likely to cause bleeding from the superior sagittal sinus , a major venous sinus located near the falx cerebri attachment.
  • ➤ crista galli
  • ➤ superior sagittal sinus

questions.text: Chassaignac’s tubercle is related with which vertebra?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chassaignac's tubercle, also called the carotid tubercle , is the anterior tubercle of the transverse process of the C6 vertebra , and it is closely related to the common carotid artery , which is palpable at this level.
  • ➤ carotid tubercle
  • ➤ anterior tubercle of the transverse process of the C6 vertebra
  • ➤ common carotid artery

questions.text: Identify the anomaly:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anencephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anencephaly is characterized by the absence of the cranial vault and brain, resulting from failure of the anterior neuropore to close during development. It is a lethal condition and a classic example of a neural tube defect.
  • ➤ Anencephaly

questions.text: Which of the following is the Widow’s artery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The left anterior descending artery (LAD. is commonly referred to as the widow's artery due to its critical role in heart function and its high association with fatal heart attacks.
  • ➤ left anterior descending artery (LAD.
  • ➤ widow's artery

questions.text: Thinnest cranial nerve is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV cranial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fourth cranial nerve (trochlear nerve) is the thinnest cranial nerve due to its minimal number of axons, as it innervates only one muscle, the superior oblique muscle .
  • ➤ fourth cranial nerve (trochlear nerve)
  • ➤ thinnest cranial nerve
  • ➤ superior oblique muscle

questions.text: Identify the central sulcus of Rolando:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The central sulcus of Rolando is the key landmark that separates the frontal lobe (motor cortex) from the parietal lobe (somatosensory cortex). It is labeled as B in this image.
  • ➤ central sulcus of Rolando
  • ➤ B

questions.text: Which nerve is most susceptible to get damage in head injury:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) VI cranial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sixth cranial nerve (abducens nerve) is the most commonly injured cranial nerve in head trauma , primarily due to:
  • ➤ sixth cranial nerve (abducens nerve)
  • ➤ most commonly injured cranial nerve in head trauma
  • ➤ Its long intracranial course . Contact with CSF in the cisterna pontis. Vulnerability at the sharp edge of the petrous temporal bone . Passage through the confined Dorello’s canal .
  • ➤ Its long intracranial course .
  • ➤ long intracranial course
  • ➤ Contact with CSF in the cisterna pontis.
  • ➤ Vulnerability at the sharp edge of the petrous temporal bone .
  • ➤ sharp edge of the petrous temporal bone
  • ➤ Passage through the confined Dorello’s canal .
  • ➤ Dorello’s canal
  • ➤ Injury to this nerve typically results in lateral rectus palsy , causing horizontal diplopia.
  • ➤ lateral rectus palsy

questions.text: Identify the related syndrome:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The condition caused by compression of the superficial branch of the radial nerve is commonly known as Cheiralgia paraesthetica, Wartenberg's syndrome, or Wrist watch syndrome , all of which describe the same pathology.
  • ➤ compression of the superficial branch of the radial nerve
  • ➤ Cheiralgia paraesthetica, Wartenberg's syndrome, or Wrist watch syndrome

questions.text: Which type of gland is depicted here?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Holocrine glands

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The gland shown in the image is a holocrine gland , specifically a sebaceous gland, characterized by the disintegration of cells to release oily secretions.
  • ➤ holocrine gland

questions.text: Your patient has lost the ability to discriminate between two points presented simultaneously to the skin. Your neurological evaluation is most likely to reveal a lesion in the
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Medial lemniscus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The medial lemniscus is part of the dorsal column pathway, responsible for fine touch, proprioception, and two-point discrimination. Damage to this structure results in the loss of two-point discrimination ability.
  • ➤ medial lemniscus

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is being examined as a candidate for cosmetic breast surgery. The surgeon notes that both of her breasts sag considerably. Which structure has most likely become stretched to result in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cooper’s ligaments

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sagging of the breasts (breast ptosis) is primarily caused by the stretching of Cooper’s ligaments, which provide suspensory support to the breast tissue. These ligaments are crucial for maintaining the breast's shape and position.

questions.text: A transverse section through the brainstem contains the nucleus of Edinger Westphal. Which other structure are you most likely to see in the same section?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Superior colliculus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Nucleus of Edinger-Westphal is located in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus , a structure associated with visual reflexes.
  • ➤ Nucleus of Edinger-Westphal
  • ➤ superior colliculus

questions.text: A 48-year-old female court stenographer is admitted to the orthopedic clinic with symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome, with which she has suffered for almost a year. Which muscles most typically become weakened in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thenar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In carpal tunnel syndrome , compression of the median nerve typically weakens the thenar muscles , which control key thumb movements, such as opposition, flexion, and abduction.
  • ➤ carpal tunnel syndrome
  • ➤ median nerve
  • ➤ thenar muscles

questions.text: Your patient has a loss of general sensation and ageusia on the posterior one third of the tongue, and touching the lateral wall of the throat fails to elicit a gag reflex. The neural structure that is the most likely to have been lesioned is the
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Damage to the glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX) results in:
  • ➤ glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX)
  • ➤ Loss of general sensation and taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue. Absence of the afferent limb of the gag reflex.
  • ➤ Loss of general sensation and taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue.
  • ➤ Absence of the afferent limb of the gag reflex.

questions.text: Your patient has a stooped posture, shuffling gait, and a tremor in the fingers at rest. Which part of the brain will show neuronal degeneration?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mesencephalon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neuronal degeneration in Parkinson’s disease occurs in the substantia nigra , located in the mesencephalon (midbrain) , which is responsible for producing dopamine crucial for motor control.
  • ➤ Parkinson’s disease
  • ➤ substantia nigra
  • ➤ mesencephalon (midbrain)

questions.text: A patient has suffered a stroke caused by occlusion of the right anterior cerebral artery. This patient is most likely to present with

options.label: A
options.text: A loss of pain and temperature sensations in the left leg

options.label: C
options.text: Drooping of the corner of the mouth on the left

questions.correct_answer: A. A loss of pain and temperature sensations in the left leg
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A loss of pain and temperature sensations in the left leg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery causes deficits in the contralateral lower limb due to its supply to the medial surface of the brain, which includes motor and sensory areas associated with the lower extremities. In this case, the loss of pain and temperature sensations in the left leg is the most likely clinical manifestation.
  • ➤ anterior cerebral artery
  • ➤ contralateral lower limb
  • ➤ loss of pain and temperature sensations in the left leg

questions.text: A lawyer suffers a bad fall that results in head trauma. His motor, sensory, and language skills are intact after the incident, and he has no visual problems. In the following weeks, he begins to lose interest in his work and doesn't seem to care much about his family. The trauma most likely affected the
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Frontal lobe

Explanation:

  • • frontal lobe
  • • frontal lobe syndrome
  • • for the lawyer’s symptoms following the head trauma.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following cells are found in the white matter of the spinal cord?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Axons

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The white matter of the spinal cord is made up of myelinated axons , which form the tracts responsible for transmitting signals throughout the CNS.
  • ➤ white matter of the spinal cord
  • ➤ myelinated axons

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Circumvallate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Circumvallate papillae are large, circular structures surrounded by trenches and contain numerous taste buds. Filiform papillae are the only papillae that lack taste buds.

questions.text: Identify the cell marked in the histological image of the cerebellum shown below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Purkinje cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Purkinje cells are large, inhibitory neurons located in the cerebellar cortex, forming a distinct layer between the molecular and granular layers.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Elastic cartilage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Elastic cartilage contains elastic fibers in its matrix, providing flexibility and resilience, and is found in structures like the external ear and epiglottis.

questions.text: All of the following are Not true about Given Histology ?

options.label: A
options.text: The cortical portion is mainly composed of lymphocytes

options.label: C
options.text: It is derived from the fourth Pharyngeal pouch

questions.correct_answer: C. It is derived from the fourth Pharyngeal pouch
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is derived from the fourth Pharyngeal pouch

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thymus is derived from the third pharyngeal pouch, contains Hassall's corpuscles in the medulla, and undergoes atrophy after puberty.
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: Shown epithelium is found in ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Urinary bladder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transitional epithelium (urothelium) is a stratified epithelium with dome-shaped, sometimes binucleated cells, found in the urinary bladder and other parts of the urinary tract.

questions.text: The movements at the _________________ joint permit a person to look
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Atlanto-axial

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The atlanto-axial joint allows rotational movement of the head (the "no" motion), enabling a person to look to the right and left.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and fully mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Parotid tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A slowly growing, mobile swelling near the parotid gland in an adult is most likely a parotid tumor. Proper evaluation, including imaging and possible biopsy, is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows widened mediastinum. BP is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute aortic dissection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute aortic dissection presents with sudden, tearing chest pain radiating to the neck and back, widened mediastinum on imaging, and blood pressure discrepancies between limbs. Immediate diagnosis and intervention are critical.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of trauma one week back presents with confusion and ataxia. He is on treatment for alcohol dependence and his last intake was 2 weeks back. CT scan reveals the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subdural hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subdural hemorrhage appears as a crescent-shaped collection on CT, often occurring after trauma due to the tearing of bridging veins. It may present with delayed symptoms, particularly in high-risk individuals like those with alcohol dependence or brain atrophy .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thyroglossal cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A thyroglossal cyst is a midline neck swelling that moves with swallowing and tongue protrusion due to its attachment to the thyroglossal duct, a remnant of thyroid gland embryogenesis.

questions.text: Cardiac dominance is decided by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior interventricular artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiac dominance is decided by the artery that gives rise to the posterior interventricular artery. Right coronary dominance is most common, occurring in 90% of individuals.

questions.text: A tumor of the uncinate process of the pancreas affects which of the following vessels?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Superior mesenteric artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A tumor in the uncinate process of the pancreas primarily affects the superior mesenteric artery and vein due to their close anatomical relationship.

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to thrombosis of which artery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Superior cerebellar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thrombosis of the superior cerebellar artery leads to ataxia and incoordination due to ischemia of the cerebellum, which is responsible for balance and motor coordination.

questions.text: Nerve of anterior compartment of thigh is.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Femoral nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The femoral nerve is the key nerve of the anterior compartment of the thigh, responsible for knee extension and hip flexion.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Interossei and lumbricals

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The interossei and lumbricals are crucial for coordinated flexion at MCP joints and extension at IP joints. Their dysfunction results in claw hand deformity, with extension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints.

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which arch artery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 6tharch

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery, which forms the ductus arteriosus (later ligamentum arteriosum).
  • ➤ Note :
  • ➤ Note

questions.text: SSA fibres are present in which of the following cranial nerves?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) I, II, VIII

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SSA fibers are found in cranial nerves I (Olfactory), II (Optic), and VIII (Vestibulocochlear), as they are responsible for the special senses of smell, vision, hearing, and balance .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves nuclei shows SSA features
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) VIII

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Among cranial nerves, only Cranial Nerve VIII (Vestibulocochlear nerve) has nuclei (cochlear and vestibular) that exhibit SSA features for hearing and balance.

questions.text: GSE fibres are present in cranial nerves:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) III, IV, VI, XII

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GSE fibers are found in cranial nerves III (Oculomotor), IV (Trochlear), VI (Abducens), and XII (Hypoglossal), as they control skeletal muscles derived from somites.

questions.text: Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery? Superior gluteal artery Inferior gluteal artery Superior vesical artery Middle rectal artery Inferior vesical artery Vaginal artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anterior division of the internal iliac artery supplies the pelvic cavity (bladder, rectum, vagina, prostate) and includes branches such as the inferior gluteal, superior vesical, middle rectal, inferior vesical, and vaginal arteries.

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Papez circuit connects the mammillary body to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus , which is involved in memory and emotional processing.
  • ➤ Papez circuit
  • ➤ mammillary body
  • ➤ anterior nucleus of the thalamus

questions.text: A 48-year-old female patient presented with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain, which is often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals multiple peptic ulcers in the duodenal bulb. Laboratory tests show elevated gastrin levels. She was given Prilosec for a long time. She was also consuming a vegetarian diet and now presented with tiredness & palpitations since a month. She complained of progressive sensory loss in her lower extremities. Neurological examination reveals impaired vibratory sensation in both legs. An MRI of the spinal cord shows no structural abnormalities. On blood examination she had following haematological slide was found. All of the following statements are correct in this case except:

options.label: A
options.text: This is a case of gastrinoma with high gastrin secretion resulting in hypersecretion of hydrochloric acid.

options.label: B
options.text: Prilosec is an example of a proton pump inhibitor which may cause decrease Vit B12 absorption.

options.label: C
options.text: In this patient due to Vitamin B 12 deficiency myelination of anterior spinothalamic tract has been affected.

options.label: D
options.text: On haematological examination Increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV, >100 fL) and mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) and polymorphonuclear cells with multiple lobes are found.

questions.correct_answer: C. In this patient due to Vitamin B 12 deficiency myelination of anterior spinothalamic tract has been affected.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) In this patient due to Vitamin B 12 deficiency myelination of anterior spinothalamic tract has been affected.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 deficiency commonly causes subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, primarily affecting the dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus) and not the anterior spinothalamic tract. Hematological findings often include macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils.
  • ➤ subacute combined degeneration
  • ➤ dorsal columns

questions.text: A 21-year-old null gravida caucasian patient presented with a 15-month history of amenorrhea, bifrontal headache, and photophobia. Examination revealed general physical, neurologic, and ophthalmoscopic findings with normal visual fields. A pelvic examination revealed normal external genitalia, nulliparous cervix and uterus, and bilateral cystic ovarian masses measuring 8 cm in diameter on the right and 4 cm on the left. Endocrine evaluation revealed an elevated serum prolactin in the range of 48 to 50 ng/ml. This situation was related with mass in the following area of the below image
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pituitary gland , located in the sella turcica (B), is the site of prolactinomas, which are the most common cause of hyperprolactinemia, leading to galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and infertility. This region can be surgically accessed via a transnasal transsphenoidal approach for treatment when needed.
  • ➤ pituitary gland
  • ➤ sella turcica
  • ➤ transnasal transsphenoidal approach

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Accessory nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI) runs obliquely in the posterior triangle of the neck , providing motor innervation to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles . Damage to this nerve can impair shoulder elevation and neck movements.
  • ➤ accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI)
  • ➤ posterior triangle of the neck
  • ➤ sternocleidomastoid
  • ➤ trapezius muscles

questions.text: Identify the marked structure?
questions.correct_answer: A. Ostium of left coronary artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ostium of left coronary artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ostium of the left coronary artery is located within the left coronary sinus of the aortic valve and plays a critical role in supplying oxygenated blood to the heart via the left coronary artery. It is an essential anatomical feature observed in the superior cross-sectional view of the heart.
  • ➤ ostium of the left coronary artery
  • ➤ left coronary sinus
